title: 104_hr2974
content: The Act is titled the "Crimes Against Children and Elderly Persons Increased Punishment Act" and it amends the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 to enhance penalties for vulnerable victims. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to increase penalties for crimes of violence against children, elderly persons, or other vulnerable individuals. The enhancement will be at least 5 levels above the offense level, or 6 levels if the crime is also a sex crime against a child. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to increase penalties for crimes of violence against vulnerable individuals, defined as those who are elderly, children, or otherwise susceptible to criminal conduct. The "Amber Hagerman Child Protection Act of 1996" increases penalties for federal sex offenses against children. The "Amber Hagerman Child Protection Act of 1996" increases penalties for federal sex offenses against children, including amendments to sections 2241(c) and 2243(a) of title 18, United States Code, imposing life imprisonment for repeat offenders. The "Amber Hagerman Child Protection Act of 1996" enhances penalties for federal sex offenses against children, including life imprisonment for repeat offenders under section 2243(a) of title 18, United States Code. Federal jurisdiction over rape and sexual assault cases is addressed in Section 5. Section 2241 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a provision for the punishment of sexual predators. Those who violate this section in specific circumstances, such as engaging in conduct across state lines with intent, will face a life imprisonment sentence. The amendment to Section 2241 of title 18, United States Code, introduces a provision for punishing sexual predators with life imprisonment if they have a prior conviction for certain offenses. SEC. 6. PROHIBITIONS RELATING TO BODY ARMOR. The "James Guelff Body Armor Act of 1996" mandates a sentencing enhancement for crimes of violence against vulnerable persons, including law enforcement officers, when the defendant used body armor. Body armor is defined as any product intended to protect against gunfire, and a law enforcement officer is broadly defined as any officer. The term "law enforcement officer" is defined as any officer, agent, or employee authorized to engage in the prevention, detection, investigation, or prosecution of criminal law violations at the federal, state, or local level. AMENDMENT OF SENTENCING GUIDELINES TO ENHANCE PENALTIES FOR CRIMES COMMITTED WITH A FIREARM EQUIPPED WITH A LASER SIGHTING DEVICE. The United States Sentencing Commission must amend sentencing guidelines to enhance penalties for crimes involving a firearm with a laser sighting device used against a vulnerable person. The House of Representatives passed the bill on May 7, 1996.
